results.title: Inside the Hollywood Home of Social Media’s Stars. (Don’t Be Shy.)
results.abstract: High jinks and networking abound at 1600 Vine Street, the apartment complex minting the next generation of Instagram and YouTube celebrities.

results.title: San Francisco’s Skyline, Now Inescapably Transformed by Tech
results.abstract: Salesforce Tower, which at 1,070 feet is the tallest office building west of the Mississippi, will be inhabited in January, signaling tech’s triumph in the city.

results.title: Unfiltered Fervor: The Rush to Get Off the Water Grid
results.abstract: Driven by misgivings about how tap water is treated, start-ups are turning to springs and the air for purer sources — and drawing an elite audience.

multimedia.caption: Opal Springs Water Company in Culver, Ore., bottles “raw water” — unfiltered, untreated, unsterilized spring water — for the start-up company Live Water.

results.title: How Antivirus Software Can Be Turned Into a Tool for Spying
results.abstract: Government officials warn that software from Kaspersky Lab could be subverted by Russian intelligence. A security researcher shows how it could be done.

multimedia.caption: Employees of Kaspersky Lab at the company’s offices in Moscow. Intelligence officials in the United States believe Kaspersky’s antivirus software was turned into a tool for spying.

results.title: Copying iPhone Messages to the Computer
results.abstract: Several inexpensive programs can easily archive text messages, voice mail, music and other content from your phone to your PC or Mac.

multimedia.caption: Programs like iExplorer can copy an iPhone’s messages, voice mail and other files to a computer.

results.title: With Disney Deal Looming, Murdoch’s Empire Is Fractured
results.abstract: Rupert Murdoch’s decision to sell most of 21st Century Fox has many wondering what the future holds for him and the two sons who seemed on the cusp of taking over his vast empire.
results.byline: By BROOKS BARNES and SYDNEY EMBER

multimedia.caption: Rupert Murdoch agreed in December to sell much of 21st Century Fox to the Walt Disney Company, leaving many wondering what the future holds for Mr. Murdoch and his two sons.

results.abstract: The launch of a new rocket by Elon Musk’s SpaceX and moon landings by India, China and private companies could occur this year, but no one is sure when.

results.title: How Do You Vote? 50 Million Google Images Give a Clue
results.abstract: Artificial intelligence is making it possible for Street Views to be mined for insights about the economy, politics and human behavior — just as text mining has done for years.

multimedia.caption: Timnit Gebru led the research effort at Stanford University that analyzed 50 million images and location data from Google Street View, the street-scene feature of the online giant’s mapping service.

results.title: Tesla the Car Is a Household Name. Long Ago, So Was Nikola Tesla.
results.abstract: The star of a man once renowned as the prototype of a genius inventor has faded. But his reputation is having a revival, and his creations still resonate.

multimedia.caption: The inventor Nikola Tesla around 1896. Tesla died a poor man in 1943 at age 86, but thanks to Elon Musk and his electric car company, “now he’s getting his due,” a biographer said.

results.title: Nintendo’s Switch Brings Some Magic Back
results.abstract: This time last year, the company that made Mario and Donkey Kong household names seemed to have lost its touch. Now, with the new console, it’s on a roll.

multimedia.caption: The Nintendo Switch, which players tested at the E3 Electronic Entertainment Expo in Los Angeles this year, has helped turn the company around.

results.title: Dealing With Destructive System Updates
results.abstract: Software updates are supposed to make your computer better, but when they do the opposite, be prepared to do some troubleshooting.

multimedia.caption: When desktop or Start Menu icons have disappeared but you can still see the program in the Control Panel, repairing it or reinstalling it may help restore the software if it was damaged in a system update.

results.title: Accused of Slowing Old iPhones, Apple Offers Battery Discounts
results.abstract: In an apologetic statement, the company said it would cut the price of iPhone battery replacements by $50 for anyone with an iPhone 6 or later.

multimedia.caption: Apple addressed criticism that it throttles the performance of iPhones with aging batteries to prevent device shutdowns with an apology that includes reducing the price of battery replacements by $50. The issue affects mainly the iPhone 6 series and iPhone SE.

results.title: Bookstore Chains, Long in Decline, Are Undergoing a Final Shakeout
results.abstract: Book World is closing its 45 stores amid the holiday shopping season, signaling the final gasps for large book sellers as e-commerce rises.

results.title: Uber Sells Stake to SoftBank, Valuing Ride-Hailing Giant at $48 Billion
results.abstract: The deal is a notable drop from the $70 billion valuation Uber once commanded, and is a humbling coda on a rough year for the company, which has been rocked by a series of scandals.

multimedia.caption: Dara Khosrowshahi, who became Uber’s chief executive in August, said he wanted to take the ride-hailing company public by 2019.

results.title: That Game on Your Phone May Be Tracking What You’re Watching on TV
results.abstract: The start-up Alphonso collects viewing data for advertisers through mobile gaming apps that can track users on the devices’ microphones, even when the apps aren’t in use.

results.title: Some Things About Tech Were Good in 2017. No, Really.
results.abstract: Amid a series of scandals and sins, a few righteous tech innovators actually brought positive change this year.

results.title: The Robots Are Coming, and Sweden Is Fine
results.abstract: In a world full of anxiety about the potential job-destroying rise of automation, Sweden is well placed to embrace technology while limiting human costs.

multimedia.caption: Oskar Pals, 19, operating a loader by remote control at the New Boliden mine in Sweden. In less than 10 years, he says, “this will then be all automated, but I am not worried — there will always be other work tasks.”
multimedia.copyright: Linus Sundahl-Djerf for The New York Times

results.title: Escaping a Malware Trap
results.abstract: Fake tech-support alerts and other poisoned web pages can put your computer at risk, so learn how to spot them and keep your security software updated.
